comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: "Albert Ballin (15 August 1857 – 9 November 1918) was a German businessman, who was the general director of the Hamburg America Line, at times the world's largest shipping company. Facing the loss of his company's ships, Ballin committed suicide by taking an overdose of sleeping pills in 1918 two days before the end of World War I. Ballin is the father of modern cruise ship travel." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Ballin

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: He was in the news in February, 1916 when the contents of an interview (attributed to Ballin) with a Bremen newspaper was published. In it, he warned, presciently, of the short and long term effects of a breach in U.S.-German relations. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E11FB3B5B1773...
